author: ART STAPLETON
title: On the Giants beat: Big Blue wary of repeat - Giants
text:
The Giants did plenty right to overcome the shortcomings everyone knew they still had during their recent three-game winning streak.
Buy this photo Giants’ Landon Collins intercepting pass intended for Eagles’ Zach Ertz during third quarter of Monday night’s loss. From midway through the first quarter to game’s end Monday night, the Giants did very little right and their flaws were exposed once again in prime time against a despised NFC East rival that played with far greater desperation.
"It’s disappointing," Giants quarterback Eli Manning said after his team’s 27-7 defeat to the Eagles. "I thought we came out ready to play. … I thought we fought hard and tried to hang in there, and really the start of the second quarter throughout the second half, we just got outplayed."
That would appear to be the best way to move past the kind of debacle the Giants slogged through yet again at Lincoln Financial Field.
Look in the mirror. Tip your cap. Get ready for the Cowboys.
It’s one bad game for the Giants, the worst they have played all season.
Their worst performance of 2014 in Philadelphia turned into seven straight losses, and they can’t let that happen again.
Dumb mistakes reveal the flaws. And in some ways, dumb mistakes are the flaws.
Now the Giants again find themselves forced to outrace their past.
Last year, bad things happened for the Giants after a touchdown pass to Larry Donnell was negated by penalty. Victor Cruz was lost for the season on the next play.
This year, while driving to the same end zone, bad things happened again after a would-be catch by Donnell was ripped away by DeMeco Ryans for an interception.
The Eagles scored 27 consecutive points last season.
The Eagles scored 27 consecutive points this season.
Collectively, the Giants had no answers.
"The sky isn’t falling," Giants left guard Justin Pugh said. "I don’t feel like this is a repeat of last year. We’re heading in the right direction and we’ll be all right. We still have everything in front of us. We’re 3-3. The Eagles are now 3-3. Dallas is 2-3.
"We’ve got everything in our sights still."
Cruz might also be ready to make another run at The Return very soon.
There is guarded optimism from the Giants regarding Cruz’s progress, a source told The Record on Tuesday. He has no pain in his left calf and is scheduled to undergo an MRI today. If all goes well, Cruz could gain clearance to begin running again and then practice, perhaps as early as this week.
It’s unlikely Cruz will be available for the Giants’ pivotal showdown with Dallas on Sunday at MetLife Stadium, but the following weekend against the Saints in New Orleans could become a realistic target date if he continues to respond to treatment.
The Giants have had no official word on a possible timetable for Cruz since he aggravated his calf injury three weeks ago.
Cruz received a platelet-rich plasma (PRP) injection Oct. 1 to help quicken the healing of his strained left calf. He attempted to practice the day before that procedure, but felt something in his calf and stopped after individual drills.
